newsitem.title: PHILIPPINES: Beijing seeks closer military ties with Manila.
newsitem.headline: Beijing seeks closer military ties with Manila.

text.p: Chinese defence minister Chi Haotian on Monday called for closer cooperation between the armed forces of China and the Philippines in talks with his counterpart, Renato de Villa.

But the thorny issue of the two countries' rival claims to the disputed Spratly Islands was not discussed in the hour-long talks and would be left to their respective foreign ministries, de Villa told reporters.
He said Chi was pleased with the "very strong" relations between the two armed forces. "He is proposing that we do some more activities together along this direction."

The Spratlys are a cluster of potentially oil-rich isles, reefs and shoals in the South China Sea which are claimed wholly or in part by the two countries as well as by Taiwan, Vietnam, Malaysia and Brunei.
Chi, speaking through an interpreter, said the two ministers agreed to push bilateral cooperation to "new levels."
"All the unsolved problems can be solved through consultations and peaceful means," Chi said.
Chinese President Jiang Zemin and President Fidel Ramos agreed in talks in Manila last November to set aside the dispute and work instead at jointly developing the contested area.
Tensions in relations between the two countries escalated in 1995 when Ramos accused the Chinese of building what looked like naval support facilities on Mischief Reef which Manila claims.

The Chinese said they were shelters for fishermen and have not dismantled them. "Our problem (over the Spratlys) will have to be worked out between the two governments," de Villa said. "There will be no provocative action or anything like that to be done by either side."
Chi, who arrived last weekend for a six-day visit, is to call on President Fidel Ramos on Wednesday. He leaves for Indonesia on Thursday.
